head.title: Song.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 7, 1796), p. 3.

body.note: Tune--Gilderoy.22 Versions of the ballad “Gilderoy” are known in the seventeenth century; it is in Ramsay’s Tea-Table Miscellany (1724; 1871 ed.), and the music is included in Musick for Allan Ramsay’s Collection of Scots Songs (1726), pp. 94-95, and then in Orpheus Caledonius (1733) II, song 47; Oswald’s Caledonian Pocket Companion, (1753), song 20, etc. See J.C. Dick, The Songs of Robert Burns (London: Frowde, 1903), p. 360; Peter Garside, et al., eds., The Forest Minstrel, by James Hogg (Edinburgh: Edinburgh U.P., 2006), p. 212. Burns used the tune for his early song “From thee, Eliza,” included in his 1786 Kilmarnock poems and his other lifetime collections; in Thomson’s Select Collection of Original Scotish Airs, I (1793), the Air is given as “Donald.” Cf. Kinsley I: 15-16 (item 9); and III: 1010-1011.

lg.l: Beneath a tree, in pensive mood,

Young Corydon33 Pastoral shepherd, generally characterized as ineffectual in love. Cf. Theocritus, Idylls 4 and 5; Virgil’s Eclogue 2; Juvenal 9.102; Petrarch, Eclogue 6.144; Sidney, Arcadia (1593); and Milton, L’Allegro 83. See Alastair Fowler, Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 48 n. 16. reclin’d;
His tears encreas’d the murm’ring flood,
His sighs, the breezy wind:
Ah me! the lovelorn shepherd cry’d,
Must this be my reward,
Must faithful lovers be deny’d,
And flatt'ring fops perferr’d?
It ne’er was mine with guilty tongue,
To feign a flame untrue;
To work a simple maiden wrong,
And innocence undo.
I ne’er, like youths of fashion, swore
By any pow’r above;
Mine eyes, my looks, and actions bore
The strongest proofs of love.
Yet see, how heedness of my truth,

The wanton Delia44 Alternative name for Artemis or Diana, Goddess of the Moon. Citing Tibullus, Maurice Scêve (1510-64) and Samuel Daniel (1562-1619), Alastair Fowler argues that Delia was often used to denote purity. See Literary Names (Oxford: Oxford UP, 2012), p. 44. strays,
Enamour’d of yon gaudy youth,
And his deceitful ways.
But ah! vain maid soon to thy cost,
That empty thing, you’ll see,
For all the passion he may boast,
Can never love like me.
